pros:
- Coworkers can be friendly and much like a community
- Free Lunch when you work a full 8 hour shift
cons: The problem that I most noticed was that they, like many other fast food jobs, purposely keep schedules to the bare-minimum number of workers they need to function (if you can consider it functioning). They keep you for as long as you can, and have the guts to get upset with you for dipping into overtime when you are asked to do so. There are tons of customers coming through, so often times you'll get the drive thru blocked up because of one person or mistake on either side, but you'll face a lot of the aggression. Multi-tasking is essential and they give you like a couple hours of training video the first day and expect you to be as competent as someone who's been there longer. There's HIGH turn around for workers, because the environment is stressful and management is not usually helpful because they're stretched thin too.

review_title: Your experience depends entirely on location
pros: I worked at two different mcdonalds. Owned by the same GM, but run very differently. I got paid base rate 14.00 at one location (former) and get paid 14.75 at my current location, 4 miles apart. the first location was super bad and mis-managed. i got called in so many times and was overworked and over scheduled to work full-time, even though i was supposed to work part-time (im a high school student). my current location is amazing. i look forward going to work as they respect me so much, and my coworkers are so fun and sweet. I hated my life at my first location and that was my mindset for every mcdonalds, until i gave this place a try. dont let one bad place fool you- it really depends all on location, coworkers, and management. i had a terrible experience not even 1 star, less than 1 star at my first location. this current location is 5 stars,love it so much. they let me leave for how ever long i want for vacation or off days as long as i tell them 2 weeks in advance. I had covid-19 and they were VERY understanding, and even gave extra days off past my quarantine time for me to recover.
cons: horrible management, they let anyone be a manager if they spend enough hours in a week working

job_title: Lead UX Researcher in Chicago, IL
pros:
- Global brand that's well-known on your resume
- Huge company 
- There are a lot of smart people
cons:
- Everyone is just a project manager, there aren't many people actually doing the work at the company. If you are, you're constantly butting heads with people who are just managing an agency to do their work, which means everyone wants to contribute their point of view to justify their presence
- A ton of bureaucracy, so many layers
- Meeting heavy culture... gotta have a meeting to discuss with everyone in the room or nothing gets done
- A lot of lifers
- Constant reorgs. Once you establish new ways of working and get into a groove and make progress, they shake things up yet again for you to start from scratch. It's awful.

review_title: Good starting Job for young people
pros:
-Free Food
-More freedom then crew 
-More desk work (Better then cleaning and on the floor work)
-The learning courses you take are free and you get paid to do them.
-Learning how to properly handle money and track it.
-Also learning common Business terms and tracking.
cons:
-Your free food isn't free we get taxed $75 for it and it's not optional.
-Very stressful every one thinks you do nothing since you are supposed to lead and not do their job.
-There is always more to do.
-Most of your desk work is easy one you get the hang of it, but till then you'll need help and will be staying late.
-None of the customer's respect you they look down at you and think you an Idiot.
-Same as above but the crew think the same of you if your a full time manger.
-Many of the poeple you work with are only in it as a way to make money and nothing more. (I've worked at 2 different stores and they feel completely different is this regard.)
- Alot of the younger crew get distracted easy.
-The older crew are frustrating sometimes.
- Some store have terrible management teams and do nothing which will make your life hell.
-Have to deal with problems that have already been built and ignored.

pros: One of many reasons to work at McDonald's is that they give opportunities to a lower-aged group. Starting from the age of 14 and going upwards. They also share different techniques and if you unlock a different technique then you step up as a crew trainer or even as a manager. Depending on the crew, they will always be a good group of people to work with , it also build up confidence for crew members who don't really enjoy talking to people. It has different duties for specific people and will always have a spot just for you.
cons: The downsides of working at McDonald's is its fast food restaurant with high expectations. Everything depends on timers, so most time the food is rushed and most likely be wrong or packed the wrong way. When it's a rush everything turns into a mess and no one has time to clean up after themselves so the best thing for them to do is make the food ontop of the mess which is highly disturbing. Most people can get impatient when it comes to waiting for there food so you have to have the positive energy and the patience towards these kind of people. It may get busy so you have to be aware that there will be many complaints about their orders.

pros: They paid me I guess that was the only positive
cons: They are mad if you want to take time off. They literally want robots who don't have feelings and never get tired. Always asked for staying extra which was not paid, we had to collect 8 hrs worth of overtime to receive one day off. Wow what a deal. When I told them I have a vacation booked, they told me that they will have to fire me when my vacation starts. They fired me, gave me notice. Few hours later they asked me to stay extra and told them NO. (You just fired me today, why the hell would I want to work extra for you??) They got mad at me and told me I was fired because of this attitude.

review_title: Pretty friendly place overall, at least for the location I worked for
pros:
- Easy work, the challenging parts might just be remembering how to prepare different burgers, operating the POS system, and dealing with troublemaker-type customers
- Flexible hours for part-time (want a day off? Tell the manager 3 weeks before so that they can ask if your colleagues are available for schedule arrangement)
- Fortunately, the place I worked for is friendly. Co-workers, supervisors, and managers are helpful to others when they have any concerns.
- You might greet new friends from the same or other colleges if the store is next to your school or in other busy areas - many college students do work in McDonald's
- Having customer service training with pay; You will automatically learn how to handle customers with a more formal and tender speech.
cons:
- Minimum pay, no surprise
- You will need to stand for hours except having meal, no matter at the kitchen or front register
- Phone use is usually prohibited under camera and managers' hawk eye, you might scroll for a few seconds, but no way for 5 minutes (but chit chat is ok when no or couple customers)
- The job experience might bearly help you, except for people who want to dive into the sales/retail/customer service area.

pros: You can ask for any days off in advance, at least a week before
